triples.name: Cooperation
triples.relevance: The paper examines the mechanisms and origins of human cooperation across societies.

triples.name: Evolutionary biology
triples.relevance: The paper employs evolutionary biology as a foundational framework to explain human social behavior.

triples.name: Psychology
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes the psychological aspects of human cooperation and cultural variation.

triples.name: Cultural evolution
triples.relevance: The paper discusses how cultural and genetic evolution interact to shape human social psychology.

triples.name: Kinship
triples.relevance: Kinship is identified as a major evolutionary mechanism explaining human cooperation.

triples.name: Reciprocity (evolution)
triples.relevance: Reciprocity is discussed as a key evolutionary mechanism underlying human cooperative behavior.

triples.name: Reputation
triples.relevance: The paper examines reputation as a mechanism enabling and reinforcing human cooperation.

triples.name: Signalling theory
triples.relevance: Signaling is analyzed as an evolutionary mechanism promoting cooperative behavior in humans.

triples.name: Punishment
triples.relevance: The paper reviews punishment as a major evolutionary mechanism enforcing human cooperation.

triples.name: Self-domestication
triples.relevance: Self-domestication is discussed as a key culture-gene coevolutionary hypothesis for human sociality.

triples.name: Social norm
triples.relevance: Norm psychology is discussed as a culture-gene coevolutionary mechanism shaping human cooperation.

triples.name: Religion
triples.relevance: The paper examines the role of religion in facilitating and regulating human cooperation.

triples.name: Marriage
triples.relevance: Marriage systems are analyzed as institutional structures shaping human social organization and cooperation.

triples.name: Primate
triples.relevance: The paper synthesizes evidence from nonhuman primates to inform understanding of human evolutionary origins.
